The Government has implemented a series of reform measures for the 
investment  climate  and  trade  aimed  at  reducing  the  cost  of  doing 
business  in  Cambodia,  including  customs  reforms  and  other  trade 
facilitation measures. Business climate reforms undertaken in the last 2 
years—many  accomplished  through  ADB’s  Small  and  Medium-Sized 
Enterprise Development Program—have also helped Cambodia to move 
up  15  places  in  the  International  Finance  Corporation’s  2008  Doing 
Business rankings. The Government is also committed to completing its 
World  Trade  Organization  (WTO)  commitments,  which  influence  how 
Cambodia  thinks  about  its  business  climate  and  trade  policy  over  the 
medium  term.  At  the  same  time,  the  Government  has  introduced  more 
prudent fiscal policies to address the surge in domestic inflation caused 
by supply-side developments in global oil and food markets.

private  sector.  The  outcome  of  the  PED  Program  will  be  an  improved 
business environment where the private sector operates efficiently and 
effectively.

THE SECTOR 

Review of the Economy, Investment Climate, and Poverty 

A. 
 
15. 
Sustained Economic Growth in 2007. After a decade of respectable growth averaging 
7.5%,  Cambodia’s  economy  accelerated  more  than  10%  in  2004  and  sustained  double-digit 
expansion  through  2007  (Table  1).  This  robust  growth  was  driven  by  industry  with  particularly 
strong performances by construction and garment making. Services were also strong, especially 
tourism, banking, and real estate.  Agriculture, which tends to be volatile, averaged 6% growth 
during  this  period.  However,  exports  soon  slowed  to  an  11%  growth  rate  in  2007,  down  from 
27% in 2006, primarily due to a sharp slowdown in garment exports. This slowdown continued 
into 2008, with garment exports rising by 5%, the lowest rate of increase in several years. Two 
million  people  visited  Cambodia  in  2007—a  record—generating  an  estimated  $1.1  billion  in 
revenue  and  helping  to  fuel  a  construction  boom  in  Siem  Reap  and  other  destinations.  Visitor 
arrivals are estimated to exceed two million in 2008. Foreign investment almost doubled in 2007 
over  2006  levels  ($900  million  versus  $475  million)  with  a  substantial  proportion  reportedly 
invested  in  real  estate,  contributing  to  the  property  price  boom.  Several  major  international 
corporations in agroprocessing and chemicals have set up representative offices in Cambodia, 
indicative of some investment diversification beginning to occur. 
 
16. 
Inflation  Surged  at  the  End  of  2007. Cambodia has achieved rapid economic growth 
with modest rates of inflation. Inflation averaged just below 4% per year between 2001 and early 

 

  

 

7

2007,  anchored  by  the  United  States  (US)  dollar  and  low  US  inflation.6 However,  by  the  third 
quarter of 2007, domestic inflation began to surge, rising from 6.4% in September to 10.8% in 
December 2007 and to 25.7% by May 2008. Inflation pressure has begun to ease since June 
with  inflation  in  July  at  22.3%  on  a  year-on-year  basis.  Domestic  inflation  was  ignited  on  the 
supply  side  by  sharply  higher  global  prices  for  petroleum  and  food  earlier  this  year,  and 
exacerbated by the depreciation of the US dollar against Cambodia’s major trading partners in 
2007.  At  the  same  time,  there  had  been  signs  that  the  economy  was  overheating—economic 
growth  in  2007  was  beginning  to  diverge  above  its  potential  growth  path;  private  sector  credit 
and broad money supply have expanded at unprecedented rates; and at the end of 2007, the 
broad  monetary  aggregates  were  about  60%  higher  than  levels  1  year  before.  Furthermore, 
excess  liquidity  in  the  banking  system  is  estimated  at  over  30%  of  deposits.  Unprecedented 
monetary  aggregate  growth  rates  in  a  hugely  inflationary  environment  increased  risks  of 
second-round  inflationary  effects  and  macroeconomic  instability.  The  National  Bank  of 
Cambodia  has  responded  by  doubling  the  reserve  requirement  from  8%  to  16%  and  relaxing 
capital outflows by allowing, upon verification, commercial banks to invest their surplus reserves 
abroad where they can earn a higher rate of return. Growth in monetary aggregates slowed to 
about 43% in the first semester of 2008 over the same period in 2007, indicating a lessening of 
inflationary pressures. 
 
17. 
Prudent  Fiscal  Policy.  The  effectiveness  of  monetary  policy  is  limited  in  a  dollarized 
economy like Cambodia, and must be supplemented with an appropriate fiscal policy stance—
for example, accumulating domestic budget surpluses when strong inflation pressures emerge 
or  when  the  economy  shows  signs  of  overheating.  Accordingly,  Cambodia’s  fiscal  policy  has 
tightened in recent years. The overall deficit narrowed significantly from over 7.0% of the gross 
domestic  product  (GDP)  in  2002  to  2.8%  in  2007,  with  improvement  reflected  in  the  current 
balance  surplus,  i.e.,  current  expenditures  less  current  revenues.  Total  revenues  have 
expanded steadily in relation to the GDP, with gains from all major tax components. On the side 
of  expenditures,  a  period  of  consolidation  ended  in  2005;  the  following  2  years  witnessed  an 
increase  in  spending  of  almost  1.5%  of  the  GDP  with  both  current  and  capital  expenditures 
rising. The approved 2008 budget is relatively expansionary on paper as it projects a fall in the 
current budget surplus from 3% in 2007 to 1% in 2008 and a small drop in government deposits 
at the National Bank of Cambodia. However, during the first half of 2008, government deposits 
rose  over  30%  and  the  annualized  budget  deficit  fell  to  0.4%  of  the  GDP,  suggesting  that  the 
actual outturn may be less expansionary (para. 20).  
 
18. 
Challenges to Sustaining Economic Growth in 2008 and 2009. Cambodia’s economy 
in 2008 and 2009 will be vulnerable to three adverse developments in the external environment: 
(i) the financial global crisis may slow foreign direct investment inflows to Cambodia as investors 
wind back global investments due to the credit crunch in developed markets; (ii) the expected 
contraction in the US and European economies in 2009 will affect the demand for Cambodian 
exports  and  visitors  to  Cambodia;  and  (iii)  the  unexpected  surge  in  international  food  and  oil 
prices  earlier  this  year,  contributed  to  higher  domestic  inflation  in  2008,  which  is  expected  to 
slow  household  consumption  and  economic  growth.  ADB  staff  forecasts  on  economic  growth 
suggest that the increases in oil prices may cut the economic growth rate by as much as 3% in 
2008  due  to  Cambodia’s  higher  fuel  content  in  production  costs.  Economic  growth  could  be 
lower  in  2009.  A  recent  International  Monetary  Fund  report  assessed  the  impact  of  global

$400 in 2005; greater labor mobility between rural and urban areas (and urbanization); higher 
rice production; private sector expansion; and improvements in market access internally and to 
neighboring  countries.  Poverty  in  Cambodia  is  primarily  a  rural  phenomenon,  with  the  official 
rural  poverty  rate  at  39%  of  the  rural  population.  Moreover,  there  are  significant  regional 
disparities  in  the  incidence  of  poverty  in  Cambodia,  with  very  low  rates  of  poverty  recorded in 
regions with higher per capita incomes (e.g., Phnom Penh, Kandal province, and Sihanoukville) 
and high rates in those with low per capita incomes (e.g., Kampong Speu, Kampong Thum, and 
Siem  Reap).  At  the  same  time,  income  inequality  has  increased,  as  measured  by  the  Gini 
coefficient, from 0.35% in 1994 to 0.40% in 2004. The widening income gap between rural and 
urban  populations  and  within  rural  populations  contributed  to  this  increase.  Rising  income 
inequality  is  typical  in  the  earlier  stages  of  development  in  a  low-income  but  fast-growing 
economy  driven  by  urban  economic  growth.  ADB  staff  poverty  simulations  indicate  that 
Cambodia could reach its Millennium Development Goal  national poverty target of 24% of the 
population by 2015, depending on achieving an economic growth rate of 7.5% (or 5% per capita 
income growth) per year from 2008 to 2015, low inflation in the range of 3% per year, and stable 
income  distribution.  However,  these  variables  have  deteriorated  in  2008,  thus  increasing  the 
probability that Cambodia may fall short of its target.

20.

creation  of  productive  jobs,  and  continue  poverty  reduction—difficult  tasks  with  half  of  the 
population  under  age  20  years  and  more  than  85%  employed  in  the  informal  sector.  The

strategy. Reforms to enhance competitiveness will require macroeconomic stability, institutional 
reforms to investment climate, competition policy, and enhanced trade facilitation measures.

Macroeconomic Stability for Private Sector Growth 

A  critical  short-term  issue  affecting  private  sector  growth  is  inflation.  Over  the 
21. 
longer term, a potential challenge for the Government will be to improve conditions for growth of 
the nonresource private sector in the event that Cambodia’s oil reserves are proven to be large 
and lead to a substantial resource boom. Integral to maintaining this growth is macroeconomic 
stability. 
 
22.  Macroeconomic  stability  is  being  tested  by  the  surge  in  domestic  inflation  that  was 
initially ignited by global food and oil price surges, and most recently, the possibility of emerging 
second-round  effects.  Authorities  will  need  to  supplement  the  recent  tightening  of  monetary 
policy  with  tighter  fiscal  policy  to  slow  aggregate  demand  and  inflation  pressures.  This  will 
require continuing to operate sizeable current budget surpluses and accumulating government 
deposits  at  the  National  Bank  of  Cambodia  above  its  current  level  of  6%  of  GDP  for  2008 
(Figure 4). 
 
23. 
A  Future  Oil  Boom  Could  Impact  Private  Sector  Development.  The  nonresource 
private sector will be influenced by future developments in the resource sector. While there are 
no definitive figures on Cambodia’s proven oil reserves and timing of future production contracts 
and  commercial  operations,  the  Government  anticipates  significant  future  revenues  from  oil 
extraction  and  other  investments  in  the  mining  sector  in  the  form  of  taxes,  royalties,  and 
dividends.  Revenue  flows  would  provide  fiscal  space  and  a  tremendous  opportunity  for 
Cambodia  to  finance  its  priority  development  goals,  raise  the  per  capita  income,  and  reduce 
poverty,  as  earlier  resource  booms  have  done  in  Indonesia  and  Botswana.  At  the  same,  a 
resource boom of long duration can affect competitiveness of the nonresource tradable goods 
sectors (agriculture and garments) if it leads to an excessive appreciation of the real exchange 
rate––i.e., where the appreciation cannot be justified on the basis of economy-wide productivity 
growth  and  investment.  There  are  important  lessons  to  be  learned  from  Indonesia  and 
Botswana in maintaining private sector growth when there is an oil boom, including maintaining 
fiscal discipline, smoothing out expenditures to avoid excessively inflationary effects of resource 
revenues  flows  in  the  economy,  and  reforming  the  business  climate  and  investments  to  raise

Competition  Policy.  In  general,  Cambodia  is  a  competitive  economy  where  many 
anticompetitive  issues  that  characterize  most  other  Southeast  Asian  economies  are  less 
relevant. For example, Cambodia is relatively open at the border. Most major nontariff barriers 
have  been  eliminated  and  tariffs  reformed,  albeit  they  are  still  relatively  high  in  some  areas. 
Cambodia  also  does  not  have  a  large  state  enterprise  sector,  normally  a  major  source  of 
anticompetitive  behavior  in  developing  economies.  However,  as  the  economy  expands  and 
becomes  more  sophisticated,  it  will  be  necessary  to  ensure  competition  in  industries  typically 
vulnerable to anticompetitive behavior, mainly traditional nontradable services, such as utilities. 
A  pragmatic  approach  to  competition  policy  would  be  to  establish  a  policy  framework  for 
competition  focusing  on  open  tariff  and  other  trade  policies,  as  well  as  deregulatory  rules  and 
guidelines overseen by independent regulatory bodies to ensure contestable utility markets, and 
establishing  a  RIA  within  the  Government  to  ensure  regulations  are  not  anticompetitive  and 
licensing  does  not  disadvantage  existing  or  potential  competitors  (i.e.,  competitive  neutral 
regulations). Regional neighbors have implemented competition policies; Indonesia’s approach 
has been to start with trade reforms, deregulation, and then privatization. At the later stages of 
implementation, the Government of Indonesia introduced a competition law and commission in 
1999.  The  commission’s  approach  has  been  pragmatic,  and  its  efforts  have  helped  trigger 
deregulation  in  a  few  sectors  (e.g.,  domestic  airlines).  However,  its  capacity  to  carry 
sophisticated economic analysis required for demonstrating anticompetitive behavior has been 
limited.

and other emerging priorities. The PED Program reduces this risk by limiting the

SECTOR ANALYSIS 1 
ASSESSMENT OF ECONOMIC GROWTH PERFORMANCE AND INVESTMENT 

Background 

 
1. 
The sector analysis assesses the recent performance of the private sector, and provides 
background for identification of issues, constraints, and threats to, as well as the Government’s 
priority reforms in support of, private sector development and growth.  
 
A. 
 
2. 
Cambodia’s  economic  performance  has  been  impressive  over  the  last  5  years.  From 
2003 to 2007, economic growth averaged around 10.5%, and the gross domestic product (GDP) 
per  capita  increased  by  over  70%  to  $598.  Based  on  the  $2-per-day  poverty  line,  poverty 
incidence  declined  by  1.6  million  persons  (18%)  during  the  same  period  (Figure  A4.1),  and 
poverty  reduction  accelerated  after  2004  when  per  capita  income  surpassed  $400.  The 
economic  growth  has  been  supported  mainly  by  the  manufacturing,  construction,  and  the 
service  sectors.  The  manufacturing  sector  was  driven  by  garment  making,  mainly  for  export, 
which  made  the  industry  vulnerable  to  external  shocks.  The  service  sector  depends  on  
tourism-related  activities;  international  visitors  to  Cambodia  continue  to  increase,  with  over  2 
million  people  traveling  in  2007,  generating  over  $1  billion  in  revenues.  More  recently,  the 
construction sector has become fast-growing, owing to large-scale public infrastructure projects 
and an increasing demand for residential properties. Several foreign investors have also moved 
forward with major property development projects. 
 
3. 
Cambodia’s  economy  has  undergone  significant  structural  transformation  since  1990, 
but  remains  narrowly  based,  with  three  sectors—garments,  construction,  and  tourist-related 
services—accounting  for  42%  of  GDP  in  2007.  The  share  of  industry  increased  from  11%  of 
GDP in 1990 to 25% in 2007, while the agriculture sector share declined from 5% to 30% during 
the same period and the service sector expanded from 33% to 39% (Figure A4.1). Cambodia’s 
structural  transformation  has  been  dependent  on  a  few  products.  Unrestricted  access  to  the 
United  States  (US)  and  European  Commission  markets  from  the  early  to  late  1990s  
jump-started  the  garment  sector,  and  preferential  access  (or  less  restrictive  arrangement 
relative  to  other  countries)  to  the  US  market  after  1999  also  drove  this  growth.  The  garment 
sector  accounts  for  70%  of  the  manufacturing  sector  (12%  of  GDP)  and  70%  of  Cambodia’s 
export revenue. The ancient temples at Angkor have attracted a continuous flow of international 
tourists  and  became  the  catalyst  of  growth  for  the  service  sector  (Figure  A4.1).  While  the 
garment  and  service  sectors  have  attracted  significant  foreign  direct  investment  in  the  past, 
sizeable foreign direct investment has recently moved to the construction sector (Figure A4.1). 
This  pattern  of  structural  change  is  expected  as  an  economy  grows  and  develops;  resources 
move  from  low-productivity  activities  in  subsistence  agriculture  and  traditional  services  to 
higher-productivity  activities  in  industry  and  other  modern  services.  This  process,  and  the 
associated  rural-to-urban  migration  that  occurs  with  this  transformation,  contributes  to  a 
reduction in poverty. 
 
4. 
The  small  and  medium-sized  enterprise  (SME)  sector  dominates  economic  activity  in 
Cambodia  and  accounts  for  substantial  employment.  According  to  latest  available  data  from 
Ministry  of  Industry,  Mines  and  Energy  (MIME),  there  are  31,149  small  industrial  SMEs  with 
fewer  than  50  employees.  However,  with  so  many  unlicensed  establishments,  it  is  difficult  to 
estimate the actual number of SMEs, especially the very small ones. Based on available data, 
food,  beverage,  and  tobacco  manufacturers  represent  the  largest  number  (82%)  of  small 
industrial  establishments.  In  the  past,  many  Cambodian  SMEs  were  unregistered,  primarily 
because  of  the  high  cost,  cumbersome  procedures,  and  a  lack  of  transparency  in  the

5. 
In the short term, Cambodia’s economy is vulnerable to two external developments. First, 
the  surge  in  domestic  inflation  fueled  by  global  oil  and  food  price  inflation  is  impacting  on  the 
economy  and  may  be  slowing  household  consumption.  Cambodia’s  agriculture  sector  will 
benefit  from  high  international  commodity  prices,  but  at  the  same  time,  higher  overall  food 
prices  will  adversely  affect  the  most  vulnerable,  in  particular  the  urban  poor  and  the  landless. 
Second,  the  expected  contraction  in  the  US  and  European  economies  is  affecting  garment 
exports,  with  exports  virtually  stagnant  in  the  first  quarter  of  2008.  Asian  Development  Bank 
(ADB)  staff  estimates  suggest  that  fuel  price  increases  could  reduce  Cambodia’s  economic 
growth rate by up to 3% in 2008 (down to 7%). Over the medium term, the garment sector will 
be  challenged  by  increasing  regional  competition  in  the  US  market,  and  its  contribution  to 
economic growth will continue to diminish. In fact, its contribution to growth fell to 1.2% in 2007 
from  an  average  of  2.3%  between  2004  and  2006.  Third,  the  global  financial  crisis  may  slow 
foreign  direct  investment  into  Cambodia.  The  recent  external  developments  also  highlight  that 
sustainable  high  growth  will  require  diversification  of  the  sources  of  growth  beyond  garments, 
tourism, and construction, which will also reduce Cambodia’s vulnerability to external economic 
shocks. 
 
6. 
Recent investment surveys and several value-chain studies have identified impediments 
to  Cambodia  realizing  its  medium-term  growth  potential  and  economic  diversification.  Surveys 
on business climate perceptions suggest that, among other factors, regulatory uncertainty and 
excessive red tape, remaining distortions in the trade regime, electricity costs, inadequate skills 
of the labor force, and corruption are major obstacles to private sector growth and development. 
Value-chain studies identify poor product quality, an inadequate standards and phytostandards 
(SPS)  policy  framework,  underdeveloped  links  between  the  rural  and  modern  sectors  of  the 
economy,  and  relatively  costly  logistics  as  constraints  to  export  diversification.  A  common 
thread  in  many  value-chain  studies  is  Cambodia’s  weak  competition  policy  framework  broadly 
defined to include remaining distortions at the border and behind the border. There are lessons 
from  the  successful  sectors  of  garments  and  tourism  for  the  development  of  other  sectors,  in 
particular  regarding  maintaining  investor  confidence.  Cambodia  must  provide  a  predictable 
policy  environment  for  the  sector  and  maintain  access  to  international  inputs  at  close  to

The  immediate  pressing  issue  is  the  acceleration  in  domestic  price  inflation  and  its

put fiscal policy on a sound path, critical issues that face the Government over the medium term 
include further efforts to raise revenues, improving efficiency in public expenditure management, 
strengthening debt management systems, and managing potential oil revenues. Important risks 
include  weaker  external  demand  and  heightened  regional  competition  for  Cambodia’s  main 
export  commodities.  The  Government  has  outlined  measures  to  address  inflation  and  has  a 
fiscal sustainability strategy supported by Asian Development Bank (ADB) programs.   
 
A. 
 
3. 
After remaining in single digits in the previous years, inflation rose significantly starting in 
September  2007.  From  an  average  of  3.9%  from  December  2002  to  2006,  year-on-year 
consumer price inflation1 surged to 10.8% in December 2007 and 25.7% in May 2008. The data 
suggest that inflation pressures have eased since June, but inflation remained high at 22.3% in 
July. 
 
4. 
The  sharp  increase  in  inflation  reflects  both  external  shocks  and  domestic  pressures. 
Available data suggests that three factors contributed to Cambodia’s surge in domestic inflation 
since the fourth quarter of 2007. First, the surge in global oil and food prices quickly transmitted 
to  domestic  food  inflation  [Figure  A5.1(i)  and  (ii)].  Second,  the  depreciation  of  the  riel  and  the 
United  States  (US)  dollar  against  the  currencies  of  Cambodia's  other  major  trading  partners 
added to imported inflation. Third, there were signs that the domestic economy was beginning to 
overheat in 2007. Tentative evidence indicates that aggregate domestic demand was beginning 
to  significantly  diverge  from  its  potential  growth  path  in  part  fueled  by  very  high  growth  in 
commercial bank lending [Figure A5.1 (iii) and (iv)]. Broad money grew at 61% year-on-year in 
December  2007  due  to  large  capital  inflows,  and  credit  to  the  private  sector  expanded  at  a 
record level of 76%. Credit growth to the private sector has moderated, expanding by 35% from 
January to July 2008.  
 
Responding  to  increasing  inflationary  pressure,  the  Government  announced  a  policy

sectors, especially real estate. On the fiscal side, the Government will maintain the balance of

C.  Poverty Impact Analysis for Policy-Based Lending  
 
Private sector  development and growth  is crucial for sustained  poverty reduction, as it  will  be the major generator of 
jobs and incomes in the future. This is particularly true in Cambodia, where almost 50% of the population is under the 
20  years  old  and  more  than  85%  of  employment  is  in  informal  activities  (mainly  subsistence  agriculture).  Removing 
regulatory  constraints  and  uncertainties  hindering  private  sector  investment  and  creating  new  businesses  is  crucial. 
Regulatory  compliance  and  transaction  costs,  which  are  more  burdensome  on  SMEs,  have  constrained  dynamic 
growth of SMEs by keeping most of them unregistered. The Government has made progress in the areas of business 
registration,  trade  facilitation,  and  private  sector  access  to  finance,  but  further  reforms  in  key  areas  are  needed  to 
strengthen the business environment. 
 
The  staff  study  to  evaluate  the  benefits  of  the  proposed  reforms  using  a  general  equilibrium  model  for  Cambodia’s 
economy  suggests  a  significant  gain  in  the  medium  term.  The  combined  welfare  effects  of  an  average  50%  cut  in 
transaction costs (informal) and a 50% across-the-board deduction in the effective rates of tariff are about 2.4% of the 
gross domestic product (GDP) over the medium term. The proposed reforms would also generate about 5% additional

Introduction 

A. 
 
To  support  the  implementation  of  the  Promoting  Economic  Diversification  (PED) 
1. 
Program,  an  advisory  technical  assistance  (TA)  grant  is  proposed  to  support  capacity 
development  and  implementation  of  policy  triggers  under  subprogram  2,  Enhancing  Private 
Sector Competitiveness.  
 
2. 
The objectives of the TA are threefold: (i) to support the Ministry of Commerce (MOC); 
Ministry of Industry, Mines and Energy (MIME); and Ministry of Economy and Finance (MEF) in 
implementing and monitoring the impact of key  policy reforms; (ii) to broaden and  deepen the 
investment and trade policy and facilitation reform agenda; and (iii) to assist with strengthening 
capacity  of  the  Executing  Agency  (EA)  and  implementing  agencies  (IAs)  to  produce  sector 
policies. The scope of the TA parallels the PED Program, covering principally the non-sanitary 
and -phytosanitary standard (SPS)-related triggers and milestones for subprogram 2.  
 
3. 
The  challenge  for  the  Government  is  to  accelerate  the  creation  of  productive  jobs  to 
sustain  Cambodia’s  already  remarkable  reduction  in  poverty—a  difficult  task  with  as  much  as 
50% of the population under the age of 20 years and over 85% of employment in the informal 
sector.  Key  to  sustaining  economic  growth  and  poverty  reduction  is  the  expansion  and 
diversification  of  the  private  sector.  With  such  expansion,  Cambodia  can  benefit  from  greater 
integration with neighboring economies, the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), 
and the rest of the world. Recent surveys and several value-chain studies identify weaknesses 
in Cambodia’s investment climate and trade regime that are impeding the country from realizing 
its potential. These include regulatory uncertainty and excessive red tape, remaining distortions 
in 
inadequate  SPS  management  systems, 
anticompetitive and informal practices, and limited access to technology and innovations. Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  staff  estimates  suggest  that  lowering  the  transaction  costs  of  doing 
business and trading by half could add $200 million to the economy over the medium term.  
 
4. 
The  TA  supports  a  core  element  of  the  Government’s  private  sector  reform  agenda. 
Under  the  PED  Program,  the  Government  is  committed  to  lowering  transaction  costs  and 
improving certainty for investors. It established a sector-wide approach to mainstream trade in 
economic policy and sketched out a medium-term strategy as articulated in its diagnostic trade 
integration  study.  These  include  regulatory  reform,  trade  policy  reforms,  enhancing  trade 
facilitation  through  customs  reforms,  and  strengthening  SPS  management  systems.  The 
Government  is  also  increasing  its  efforts  to  complete  implementation  of  its  World  Trade 
Organization  (WTO)  accession  commitments,  which  will  influence  the  way  in  which  the 
Government conducts trade policy over the medium term. In this regard, MOC has established 
the  WTO  Department  responsible  for  ensuring  consistency  between  domestic  policy  and 
obligations made under WTO accession, and notifying WTO of tariff barriers to trade and SPSs
